user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_QueueDelete_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_QueueDelete_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32                            return_code;
    OS_impl_queue_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_queue_table, *token);

    /* Try to delete and unlink the queue */
    if (mq_close(impl->id) != 0)
    {
        OS_DEBUG("OS_QueueDelete Error during mq_close(). errno = %d (%s)\n", errno, strerror(errno));
        return_code = OS_ERROR;
    }
    else
    {
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_QueueDelete_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_queue_internal_record_t OS_impl_queue_table[OS_MAX_QUEUES]
...
typedef struct
{
    mqd_t id;
} OS_impl_queue_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragments in the provided function are demonstrably unreachable. Reasoning: 
- Control flow: both branches of the conditional (mq_close() != 0) are reachable at runtime depending on mq_close() result; the function always returns via the final return return_code; there are no statements following an unconditional return or goto that would be impossible to reach. 
- Macro expansions: OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET expands to &tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))]; with the call OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(..., *token) this becomes OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&( *token )) i.e. OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(token), so the macro usage does not introduce an unreachable path. 
- The OS_DEBUG macro is defined empty; that only removes the debug call at preprocessing time (dead/removed code), but does not create an unreachable branch in the source-level control flow. 
- There are no conditional compilations, placed returns, infinite loops, or other constructs in this snippet that would produce unreachable source code per MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1. 

Note: There are other potential concerns (e.g. lack of token validity/index bounds checking, use of mq_close error handling), but these are not instances of unreachable code and thus are outside the scope of Rule 2.1 investigation.
